text: [Music]
hey everyone thank you all so much for
being here for our second rey summit
this has been an amazing year for ray
we've seen tremendous growth
in the community in developers and
companies contributing back to the open
source project
we have over 480 contributors and we're
seeing more and more companies
building internal teams to invest in ray
one of the things that makes ray special
and where we've seen a lot of growth
is its library ecosystem and we've seen
a ton of investment in this ecosystem
as a reminder of how the ecosystem ties
in
ray is a universal framework for
distributed computing it's very general
and that generality is important for
supporting this rich
library ecosystem everything from
training
to production serving to data processing
and of course by running these libraries
on top of ray
you can use them together and build
applications that do all of these things
and if you use ray then you can run your
applications anywhere
on any cloud provider on kubernetes
or on your laptop and each of these
components adds value
for the users of the other components
so what's new with the ecosystem since
our last summit
there's been a ton of effort to ensure
that the best libraries for machine
learning
run on rey and that ray is the best way
to scale these libraries
xgboost is one example and you'll hear
at this summit
how uber has sped up training by 5x
by deploying xgboost on rey you'll also
hear
how deploying horovod on rey has allowed
them to consolidate their deep learning
and traditional machine learning stacks
by deploying on ray all these libraries
can immediately leverage
ray's elasticity auto scaling and hyper
parameter tuning
and that's how rey is helping to bring
common infrastructure to the production
ml ecosystem another example is das
which has a great library for data
processing amazon has managed to speed
up an important desk workload
by 13x by deploying dask on ray
they were able to scale the clusters
seven times larger
and the end-to-end cost job cost only 30
of the original saving over half a
million dollars per job
and of course the real benefit of rey is
that these libraries do not
exist in isolation but that they can be
used seamlessly together
in a common application with all of
these examples
we've seen that rey is becoming the tool
of choice for scaling libraries
beyond the ecosystem this year we've
seen ray being used for applications
far beyond where we were just one year
ago one of the biggest shifts
is a focus on online production use
cases
we have an incredibly broad user base
and you'll hear from every single one of
these companies
at the summit and their use cases are
equally broad
you'll hear about how they're using ray
to build scalable infrastructure for
financial services
to optimize recommendations and in-app
purchases
to do large-scale machine learning on
aerial imagery
and more later today you'll hear how
mckinsey and quantum black

and designed the boat in this picture
using rey to do reinforcement learning
and doing that
they won the america's cup which is the

you'll hear how dendra is using ray for

for providing the compute infrastructure
the training
the inference and computer vision at a

you'll hear from a panel with uber
shopify and robin hood
how they're building machine learning

and the list goes on there are so many
inspirational use cases
and that's what excites us thank you all
so much for making rey what it is
for pushing the boundaries pioneering
new use cases
and for building such a rich ecosystem
we wouldn't be here without the
community
now i'm going to transition to saying a
few words about some of the development
that's happened over the past half year
last race summit we released ray 1.0 and
announced an increased focus
on maturity and stability since then
there's been a huge effort on improving
robustness and scalability
ranging from object spilling that is
handling the scenario where your data
is way larger than your memory to
improved memory management
and significant scalability testing and
benchmarking if you're curious
about the kind of applications that this
work has enabled
check out patrick's talk from amazon to
hear how they used ray
to increase the throughput of data
processed to over a petabyte per hour
while decreasing costs by 90
or check out how chen's talk from ant
group on how they deploy
ray on over 200 000 cores
we've also put a ton of effort into
streamlining some of the workflows for
development and production
one important feature is the ray client
if you're developing on your laptop
and you have a ray driver program
running some code that's great
if you want to scale that program with a
cluster then you have to leave your
laptop
and take that driver program and run it
on some node in the cluster
this might even require you to add a new
node to the ray cluster
just to run the driver program now with
the ray client feature
instead you can continue to run the
program on your laptop
you never have to leave your laptop and
you can connect directly to the cluster
essentially to extend your laptop with
the cluster
now because you never have to leave your
laptop you don't have to ssh to the
cluster
the development workflow can be way
simpler
and this isn't only useful for
development imagine that instead of your
laptop
you want to run a scalable array
application from your continuous
integration testing
or imagine you want to kick off a ray
application from a web server
your ci and your web server may not be
part of the ray cluster
but even so they can still use ray as if
they were
thanks to this feature this is a
powerful feature that i hope you'll try
out
another feature is environments suppose
i'm connecting to a cluster
here i'm using the ray clients this is
about solving the question
how do i configure the environment that
my application runs in for example
how do i install the the dependencies on
the cluster all the python packages or
conda environments
how do i sync my code to the cluster
what if the cluster is auto scaling and
new nodes are coming online
what if i have two applications that run
on the same cluster but use different
libraries or different code
and so on well the answer is that you
can just define an environment
just specify the python dependencies in
a list
they'll be installed on all the nodes
you can also use
conda packages and those will be
installed in all the nodes as well
you can specify where your code lives
and that code will be synced to all
of the nodes and that's it it just works
even if the cluster is auto-scaling and
new nodes are being added
even if you have multiple clients
running jobs on the same ray cluster
but using different libraries and code
that's fine
it'll all just work there's a ton more
to this and a lot of ongoing development
but this dramatically simplifies the
iteration time
and process of configuring your cluster
environment
we also have invested a ton in
production serving with reyserv
we've revamped the api for simplicity
and re-architected the system for
scalability
and you can check out the talks from any
scale ikigai labs
and ant group on production serving with
ray
it's been a remarkable year and we will
continue to double down
on these foundations scalability and
robustness
streamlining the workflows for
development and production
and supporting production services and
applications
i want to welcome you all to ray summit
thank you for attending and being a part
